(I) When essential goods are in short supply various types of orders are issued. under the Essential Commodites Act, 1955, with a view to making the goods available to the consumer at a fair price. Such orders sometimes pro- vide that a person in need of an essential commodity like cement, cotton, coal or iron and steel must apply to the prescribed authority for a permit for obtain- ing the commodity. Those wanting to engage in the business of supplying the commodity are also required to possess a dealer's licence. A permit holdt:r can obtain the supply of goods to the extent of the quantity specified in the permit from the named dealer only and at a controlled price. The dealer who is asked to :.upply the stated quantity to the permit holder has no option but to supply the stated quantity of goods at the controlled price. (Para 1) (2) The view expressed in Gannon Dunkerley's case 1959 SCR 379 that the words ''sale of goods" in Entry 48, List II of the Government of India Act, 1935, must be interpreted in the sense which they bear in the Sale of Goods Act, 1935 and that the meaning of those words should not be left to fluctuate with the definition of "sale" in laws relating to sales of goods which might be in fon.:e for the time being, may require reconsideration. But assuming that a sale 1s necessarily a consensual transaction and if the parties have no voht1on or option to bargain it could not be a sale, the transactions which are the ~ubject-matter of these appeals will amount to salas. The limitations imposed by the control orders on the normal right of delllers and consumers to supply and obtain the goods, the obligations imposed on the parties and the penalties prescribed do not militate against the position that eventually the parties must be deemed to have completed the transactions under an agree- ment by which one party has bound itself to supply the stated quantity of goods to the other at a price not higher than the notified price and the other consented to accept the goods on the terms and conditions mentioned in the permit or the order of allotment issued in its favour by the concerned autho- rity. Offer and acceptance need not always be in an elementary form nor indeed doe:. the law of contract or the sale of goods require that consent to a contract must be express. It is commonplace that offer and acceptance could be spelt out from the conduct of the parties which covers not only their acts, but omissions as well. Law does not require offer and acceptance to conform to any set pattern or formula. In urder, therefore, to determine whether the1e is any agreement or consensuality between the parties regard must be had to their conduct at or about the time when the goods changed hands. In the first place, 1t is not obligatory for a trader to deal in essential commodities nor on any one to acquire it. The primary fact therefore is that tlic decision or the trader to deal in an essential commodity is volitional. Such volition carries with it the willingness to trade in the commodity strictly on the terms of the control orders. The consumer too who is under no legal compulsion to acquire or posses~ the controlled commodity decides, as a matter of his volition. to obtam it on the te1ms of the permit or the order of alloi.ment issued m his favour. That brings the two parties together - one who is willing to :.upply the essential commodity and the other to receive. When the allottee prc..,ents his permit to the dealer, he signifies his willingness to obtain the com- modity from the dealer on the terms stated in the permit. His conduct reflects his consent and when upon the presentation of the permit the dealer acts upon 1t he impltedly agrees to supply the commodity to the allottee on the terms by which he has voluntarily bound himself to trade in the commodity. His conduct too reflects his consent.
